title: SB 1073
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 17052 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow an earned income tax credit against the "net tax" for taxable years starting January 1, 2015. The credit amount is determined based on Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code, with adjustments specified in the annual Budget Act. The credit is only applicable when resources are allocated for oversight and auditing by the Franchise Tax Board. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage for eligible individuals with qualifying children are as follows: 
- No qualifying children: 7.65%
- 1 qualifying child: 34%
- 2 qualifying children: 40%
- 3 or more qualifying children: 45%
The earned income amount and phaseout amount for eligible individuals with qualifying children are:
- No qualifying children: $3,290
- 1 qualifying child: $4,940
- 2 or more qualifying children: $6,935
Certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are modified for the state's tax credit purposes. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified for the state's tax credit purposes. Changes include adjustments to withholding requirements, place of abode, and income thresholds. Additionally, inflation adjustments will be recomputed annually starting from January 1, 2016. The Franchise Tax Board may prescribe rules for implementing the tax credit. Refunds under this section are treated like federal earned income refunds for determining eligibility for benefits. The Board is exempt from certain requirements for implementing the credit for the 2015 taxable year. The Franchise Tax Board is required to include scope, costs, and schedule changes for the California Earned Income Tax Credit in its Special Project Report. The purpose of the credit is to reduce poverty among working families and individuals, with annual reporting on the number of tax returns claiming the credit, individuals represented, and average credit amount. The Franchise Tax Board is mandated to provide a report on the California Earned Income Tax Credit, including details on the average credit amount claimed, distribution by dependents and income ranges, and estimates on lifting families out of deep poverty. The tax credit is referred to as the California Earned Income Tax Credit. The amendments to this section apply to taxable years starting on or after January 1, 2016.
